# 8.4 Creating Personal Relaxation Routines ## Learning Objectives By the end of this session, you'll be able to: - Use quick ways to calm down when you feel stress - Pick the right calm-down tool for each type of stress ## Materials Needed - Notebook or phone for stress journal - Comfortable pillow, blanket, or stuffed animal - Personal items that help you feel calm (photos, drawings, special objects) - Timer or clock (optional) - Paper and pencils/markers for drawing peaceful place (optional) Everyone faces stress - kids and teens included. Fortunately, simple techniques can help you manage it effectively. This lesson introduces relaxation methods you can personalize to fit your needs. You'll discover various approaches - from quick solutions for sudden stress to deeper practices for when you have more time. ## Quick Stress-Busters These rapid techniques help when stress appears suddenly: **Deep Breathing** 1. Sit up straight or stand tall 2. Breathe in slowly through your nose while counting to 4 3. Hold your breath for a count of 2 4. Breathe out slowly through your mouth for a count of 6 5. Repeat 3 times **Stretch It Out** 1. Reach your arms up high toward the ceiling 2. Slowly bend to one side, then the other 3. Roll your shoulders backward 5 times 4. Gently turn your head from side to side **The 5-4-3-2-1 Game** Look around and find: - 5 things you can see - 4 things you can touch - 3 things you can hear - 2 things you can smell - 1 thing you can taste ---stopandreflect--- **CHECKPOINT:** Which of these quick stress-busters do you think might work best for you when you're feeling stressed at school? How does your body typically feel when you're stressed out? ---stopandreflectEND--- ## Short Relaxation Breaks **Relaxing Your Muscles** 1. Find a comfortable spot to sit or lie down 2. Start at your toes and squeeze them tight for 5 seconds 3. Release and feel them relax 4. Move up to your feet, then legs, and continue all the way to your face 5. Notice how different your body feels when you finish
**Mini Movement Break** 1. March in place for 30 seconds 2. Do 10 arm circles forward and backward 3. Stretch your arms out wide, then give yourself a hug 4. Gently twist your upper body from side to side 5. End with 5 deep breaths **Safety Note:** Stop immediately if any movement hurts. These activities should feel good, not painful! **Troubleshooting Tips:** - If you can't focus: Try setting a timer so you don't worry about time - If you feel silly: Practice when alone until it feels more natural - If you can't get comfortable: Use pillows or try a different position - If your mind keeps wandering: That's normal! Just gently bring your attention back each time ## Longer Calming Practices For deeper relaxation when time allows: **Peaceful Place Journey** 1. Find a quiet spot where you won't be disturbed 2. Sit or lie down comfortably 3. Close your eyes and take 5 deep breaths 4. Imagine a place where you feel completely safe and happy 5. What do you see there? What sounds do you hear? 6. Can you feel the temperature? Are there any smells? 7. Spend 10 minutes exploring this special place in your mind 8. When you're ready, slowly open your eyes **Activity Extension:** Draw or write about your peaceful place after you finish. Include as many details as possible about what you saw, heard, felt, and smelled. Keep this description nearby to remind you of this place when you feel stressed. **Gentle Movement Flow** 1. Start by standing tall, feet hip-width apart 2. Raise your arms slowly as you breathe in 3. Lower them as you breathe out 4. Gently bend forward, only as far as feels comfortable 5. Roll back up slowly, one vertebra at a time (that means one back bone at a time) 6. Repeat this flow 5-10 times, moving with your breath 7. End by standing still and noticing how your body feels **Adaptation Options:** - Limited space? Try the Gentle Movement Flow while sitting in a chair with smaller movements - Physical limitations? Stay seated and focus on arm movements and breathing - Difficulty concentrating? Start with just 2-3 repetitions and gradually build up - Need more challenge? Add gentle twists or side bends between movements ## When to Use Different Techniques Match your relaxation tools to specific situations: **Use Quick Stress-Busters when:** - You feel suddenly nervous before a test - You're frustrated with homework - You're about to have a difficult conversation - You notice your heart beating fast **Try Short Relaxation Breaks when:** - You need a study break - You feel tired but still have work to do - You want to calm down after playing or exercising - You're having trouble focusing **Use Longer Calming Practices when:** - You have time before bed to wind down - You feel overwhelmed by big emotions - You need deep relaxation after a busy day - You want some proper self-care time on weekends **Tracking Activity:** Create a simple stress journal using a notebook or your phone. Each time you feel stressed, write down: 1. What caused the stress 2. Which technique you used 3. How well it worked (1-5 stars) **What You Need:** - A comfortable spot to sit or lie down - Something soft (pillow, blanket, stuffed animal) - Items that help you feel calm (pictures, small objects) **Setting Up Your Space:** 1. Choose a quiet corner of your room or home 2. Make it comfortable with pillows or blankets 3. Add things that make you happy (photos, drawings, special items) 4. Keep it clean and organised **No Space? No Problem!** If you don't have much room: - Use a special pillow that becomes your "calm spot" - Create a small box with calming items you can take anywhere - Hang a picture that reminds you to breathe and relax ![Image: Example of a simple calm-down corner with pillows and minimal materials] **Setup Checklist:** - [ ] Found a location (even if small) - [ ] Added at least one comfortable item - [ ] Included something visual that calms me - [ ] Made sure I can use this space for at least 10 minutes uninterrupted - [ ] Tested the space by practicing one relaxation technique there ## Wrap-Up Congratulations! You've built your personal stress-busting toolkit. Managing stress improves with practice, just like any skill. Experiment with different techniques to find what works best for you. Your toolkit will evolve as you grow. **Final Reflection Activity:** 1. Write down three situations from the past week when you could have used a relaxation technique 2. For each situation, note which technique would have helped most 3. Set a specific goal for using your new skills this week (Example: "I will use deep breathing before my math test on Thursday") 4. After one week of practice, review what worked well and what you want to adjust
Remember: These skills take practice! Be patient with yourself as you learn what works best for you. ---keytakeaways--- ## Key Takeaways - Different relaxation techniques work for different situations - quick stress-busters help in sudden stress moments, while longer practices are better when you have more time. - Creating your own calm-down space, even if it's small, gives you a special place to practice relaxation techniques. - Regular practice of relaxation techniques helps you manage stress better, just like any other skill you're learning. ---keytakeawaysEND---
instructions:
This document provides detailed instructions for restructuring lesson 8.4 "Creating Personal Relaxation Routines" to more explicitly align with the stress-reduction benefits of movement outlined in lesson 8.3. The restructured lesson should maintain the core relaxation concepts while demonstrating how specific techniques address each mechanism of stress relief through movement.
Primary Restructuring Goal
Transform lesson 8.4 to explicitly connect relaxation techniques with the four key ways movement reduces stress from lesson 8.3:

Releasing feel-good brain chemicals (endorphins)
Burning off excess energy
Improving sleep quality
Taking the mind off worries

Detailed Restructuring Instructions
1. Revised Learning Objectives
Modify the learning objectives to include:
By the end of this session, you'll be able to:
- Select appropriate movement-based relaxation techniques based on your stress needs
- Match specific relaxation activities to the four ways movement reduces stress
- Create personalized relaxation routines that target your unique stress patterns
- Design a calming space that supports your relaxation practice
2. Introduction Section Enhancement
Expand the introduction to explicitly connect to lesson 8.3 concepts:
In our previous lesson, we learned how movement helps beat stress in four key ways: releasing feel-good brain chemicals, burning off extra energy, improving sleep, and shifting focus away from worries. Now, we'll build on this knowledge by creating personalized relaxation routines that target each of these areas. By matching specific techniques to your unique stress needs, you'll develop a comprehensive toolkit for managing stress effectively.
3. Restructured Content Organization
Replace the current "Quick Stress-Busters," "Short Relaxation Breaks," and "Longer Calming Practices" sections with four new categories that directly mirror the stress-relief mechanisms:
A. "Endorphin Boosters: Techniques That Release Feel-Good Chemicals"
These activities trigger your brain to release endorphins - your body's natural mood lifters:

**Joy Jumps**
1. Stand with feet hip-width apart
2. Jump up with arms reaching skyward
3. Land softly with knees slightly bent
4. Repeat 10-15 times, focusing on the joy of movement
5. Notice the mood boost that follows

**Rhythm and Dance**
1. Play a song with a steady beat (or imagine one)
2. Move your body in ways that feel good for 1-2 minutes
3. Focus on fluid, rhythmic movements
4. Allow yourself to smile as you move
5. Notice the positive feelings that emerge

**Success Stretches**
1. Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart
2. Inhale deeply while raising arms overhead in a V-shape
3. Hold this "victory pose" for 10 seconds
4. Release with an audible exhale
5. Repeat 3 times, imagining accomplishment with each stretch
B. "Energy Releasers: Movements That Calm Restlessness"
When you feel jittery or restless, these activities help burn off that excess energy:

**Progressive Tension-Release**
1. Starting with your feet, tighten muscles for 5 seconds
2. Release completely and notice the difference
3. Work upward through each muscle group
4. End with facial muscles, scrunching then relaxing
5. Notice how different your body feels afterward

**Stress Ball Squeezes**
1. Find a stress ball or make one (sock filled with dry rice)
2. Squeeze firmly for 5 seconds
3. Release slowly, feeling tension leave
4. Repeat 10 times with each hand
5. Notice how your hands and arms feel more relaxed

**Wall Push**
1. Stand arm's length from a wall
2. Place palms flat against the wall at shoulder height
3. Lean in, bending elbows slightly
4. Push against the wall firmly for 10 seconds
5. Release and feel the energy discharge
C. "Sleep Preparers: Calming Movements for Better Rest"
These gentle activities prepare your body and mind for quality sleep:

**Bedtime Body Scan**
1. Lie comfortably on your back
2. Starting at your toes, gently wiggle then relax each body part
3. Move upward through your entire body
4. Notice areas of tension and consciously release them
5. Complete the scan with three deep breaths

**Nighttime Stretching Sequence**
1. Sitting on your bed, gently reach arms overhead
2. Slowly bend forward, letting your head and arms hang down
3. Hold for 30 seconds, breathing deeply
4. Roll back up slowly, one vertebra at a time
5. Repeat 3 times, noticing increased relaxation

**Gentle Rocking**
1. Sit comfortably on the edge of your bed
2. Gently rock your upper body forward and back
3. Keep movements slow and rhythmic
4. Continue for 1-2 minutes while breathing deeply
5. Notice how this natural movement signals your body to prepare for sleep
D. "Mind Clearers: Activities That Shift Your Focus"
When worries fill your mind, these techniques redirect your attention to the present moment:

**Mindful Walking**
1. Walk slowly in a small space (even 10 steps back and forth)
2. Notice every sensation - feet touching the ground, muscles moving
3. Count your steps from 1-10, then start over
4. If thoughts intrude, acknowledge them and return to counting
5. Continue for 2-3 minutes, staying fully present with the movement

**Balance Challenge**
1. Stand on one foot
2. Focus completely on maintaining balance
3. Hold for 30 seconds, then switch feet
4. If your mind wanders, gently bring focus back to balancing
5. Notice how focusing on balance leaves little room for worry thoughts

**The 5-4-3-2-1 Movement Game**
1. Do 5 different movements with your fingers (wiggle, snap, tap, etc.)
2. Perform 4 movements with your hands (clap, wave, circle, etc.)
3. Try 3 movements with your arms (reach, swing, hug yourself)
4. Do 2 movements with your legs (march, knee lift)
5. Finish with 1 full body movement (gentle twist, stretch, or sway)
4. Create a New "Movement-Stress Connection Chart"
Add this activity to help students connect techniques to specific needs:
**Personalized Technique Matching**

Complete this chart to identify which techniques work best for your specific stress patterns:

| When I experience... | This technique helps because... | When I'll use it |
|----------------------|--------------------------------|------------------|
| Racing thoughts | [Mind clearer technique] | [Specific situation] |
| Physical restlessness | [Energy releaser technique] | [Specific situation] |
| Low mood | [Endorphin booster technique] | [Specific situation] |
| Difficulty sleeping | [Sleep preparer technique] | [Specific situation] |
5. Enhance the "Creating Your Calm-Down Space" Section
Modify this section to connect with movement concepts:
## Creating Your Movement-Friendly Calm-Down Space

A dedicated space for your relaxation routines makes it easier to practice regularly. Here's how to create a space that supports movement-based stress relief:

**What You Need:**
- Enough room to extend your arms and take at least one step in each direction
- A comfortable surface for floor exercises (mat, carpet, blanket)
- Something to mark the boundaries of your space (pillow, tape outline, special rug)
- Optional items that signal "relaxation time" (special pillow, calming image, soft light)

**Setting Up Your Space:**
1. Choose a location where you can move without bumping into things
2. Make sure the space accommodates standing, sitting, and lying down positions
3. Keep the area clear of distractions and hazards
4. Add personal touches that help you feel calm and focused

**No Space? No Problem!**
If you don't have much room:
- Create a "movement corner" with just enough space for standing balance exercises
- Use your bed space for seated and lying down techniques
- Designate a special mat that, when unrolled anywhere, becomes your movement space
6. Add a New "Matching Techniques to Needs" Section
Create this additional section to help students apply the right techniques at the right time:
## Choosing the Right Technique for Your Needs

Different stress situations call for different relaxation approaches. Here's how to match techniques to specific needs:

**When to use Endorphin Boosters:**
- When you're feeling sad or down
- After receiving disappointing news
- When you need motivation to start a difficult task
- First thing in the morning to set a positive tone

**When to use Energy Releasers:**
- Before situations requiring focus (like tests or important conversations)
- When you feel fidgety or can't sit still
- After sitting for long periods
- When you feel nervous energy before an event

**When to use Sleep Preparers:**
- As part of your nightly routine, 30-60 minutes before bed
- When you've had a particularly busy or stressful day
- If you wake up during the night and have trouble falling back asleep
- When transitioning between high-energy and calm activities

**When to use Mind Clearers:**
- When worries keep circling in your mind
- Before starting homework or creative projects
- During short breaks between tasks
- When you need to shift from one activity to another
7. Enhance the "Tracking Activity" Section
Expand the stress journal concept to specifically track movement effects:
**Movement-Effect Tracking:** 
Create a stress-relief journal using a notebook or your phone. Each time you use a movement technique, note:

1. What stress symptoms you were experiencing
2. Which technique you used
3. Which of the four stress-relief mechanisms you were targeting
4. How you felt immediately after (1-5 stars)
5. How you felt 30 minutes later (1-5 stars)

This tracking helps you discover which techniques work best for your unique stress patterns and situations.
8. New Concluding Section
Add a final section that reinforces the movement-stress connection:
## Your Complete Movement-Based Stress Relief Toolkit

Congratulations! You've now built a comprehensive toolkit of movement-based relaxation techniques that address all four ways physical activity combats stress:

1. **Endorphin Boosters** release feel-good brain chemicals that lift your mood
2. **Energy Releasers** burn off excess stress energy that causes restlessness
3. **Sleep Preparers** calm your body and mind for better quality rest
4. **Mind Clearers** shift your focus away from worries to present-moment awareness

Remember that these skills improve with practice, just like any physical activity. Start with just one or two techniques that appeal to you most, then gradually expand your repertoire as you become more comfortable.

By matching specific techniques to your unique stress patterns and needs, you're developing essential self-care skills that will serve you throughout your life. The ability to recognize and address stress through movement is a powerful tool for maintaining both physical and emotional wellbeing.
Implementation Notes

The restructured lesson maintains all the core elements of the original (relaxation techniques, personal space creation, implementation planning) while organizing them around the movement-stress connection framework.
New techniques have been added that explicitly demonstrate each stress-relief mechanism, with clear instructions for implementation.
The new structure helps students make direct connections between their stress symptoms and the appropriate movement-based interventions.
Language and instructions remain age-appropriate and accessible for middle school students while introducing some key concepts about how movement affects stress physiology.
The restructured lesson can use the same materials as the original but creates a stronger conceptual bridge between lessons 8.3 and 8.4.

It also covers setting up a personal calm-down space and tracking the effectiveness of different techniques. The content aims to equip students with a toolkit of strategies to address stress in different situations.

## Enhancement Requirements
The primary goal of the enhancement is to restructure the lesson to more explicitly connect the relaxation techniques to the four key ways that movement reduces stress, as outlined in the previous lesson 8.3. The enhanced lesson should:

- Age Range: 11-14 years old (grades 6-8)
- Reading Level: 5th-6th grade on Flesch-Kincaid scale
- Language: English-speaking students
- Prior Knowledge: Varying exposure to physical education concepts, possibly limited formal PE instruction
- Learning Style: Visual demonstrations, simple explanations, hands-on activities
- Physical Space/Equipment: Limited access to specialized equipment, varying home spaces available

## Learning Medium Considerations
The content will be delivered through Excel Middle School's asynchronous online curriculum, with no peer interaction. This means the material must be self-contained and easy to navigate without instructor guidance. Formatting, organization, and visual aids will be particularly important to engage learners and support independent study.

## Key Considerations
- Maintain the core relaxation concepts and techniques from the original content
- Clearly demonstrate how each relaxation technique addresses the four stress-relief mechanisms of movement
- Provide a structured framework for students to match techniques to their unique stress patterns and needs
- Emphasize the importance of regular practice and personalization of the relaxation toolkit
- Ensure the content is accessible, engaging, and appropriately adapted for the target middle school audience

The enhanced lesson should retain the original content's educational integrity while restructuring the material to more explicitly connect relaxation techniques to the movement-stress relief framework. The new organization, activities, and guidance will help students develop a comprehensive understanding of how movement-based relaxation can effectively manage their stress.

Key elements to incorporate:
- Revised learning objectives that focus on technique selection, stress-relief mechanism matching, and personalized routine creation
- Expanded introduction that bridges to the previous lesson's concepts
- Four new content sections aligned with the stress-relief mechanisms of movement
- "Personalized Technique Matching" activity to help students identify their unique needs
- Enhanced "Calm-Down Space" guidance for movement-friendly environments
- "Choosing the Right Technique" section to support appropriate application
- Expanded "Tracking Activity" to monitor the effects of movement-based relaxation
- Concluding section that reinforces the movement-stress connection

By providing this comprehensive preparatory context, the subsequent content enhancement can effectively transform the original lesson to better serve the target learners' needs while preserving the core educational value.
